sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: WebExports
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties which will be automatically exported if this protocol is published as a web service.

Each global property in the list is created with an empty value at the start of the protocol run.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Form
sci:arg.sci:help: The path to a protocol that will render an HTML user interface for this protocol. This optional parameter is used by Webport to provide a custom user interface for a protocol.

sci:arg.name: OnGeneralError
sci:arg.sci:help: When a recoverable error occurs during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) portPass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: OnDataTypeError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an expected data type is not found during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the networkFail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) portPass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: A top-level component for building protocols.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: The user should customize this description and usage to describe the functioning of their derived protocol.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: This is the help window for working with components and protocols in Pipeline Pilot. To create a protocol, drag items from the Components tab into the workspace. Connect them with pipes, edit their parameters, and then click Run to generate results. As you select components and protocols, information about using them is displayed in this help window. The parameters are displayed in the adjacent Parameters window.For more information, go to Getting Started with Pipeline Pilot.

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:value: M2 Similarity MatchingSupply two SD files and similar structures will be grouped together

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: Location of the component in the database

sci:arg.name: Source
sci:arg.sci:help: The file or URL source to read

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to read (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: SourceTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called SourceTag is created and holds the value indicated.

  • None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
  • Filename: The name of the file read.
  • FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
  • FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
  • ZipFilename: When reading a compressed zip file, the filename within the compressed archive.
  • Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...
  • Letter: When multiple files are read in this component, they are lettered A, B, C...
  • KeepCurrent: Keeps the current value of SourceTag.

sci:arg.name: Keep Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of properties the reader should retain for each data record that is output. If a value is not defined, retains all properties. If the parameter contains the value "-" (minus sign), properties are not retained.

sci:arg.name: SD Format Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options available for the SD Reader:

  • Properties Can Contain $$$$: By the MDL CTFile standard, a property can contain a '$$$$'-line. Properties or data field values are terminated by a blank line. Only then will the '$$$$'-line terminate the full data block. Setting this option off will terminate the data block upon any read of a '$$$$'-line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • One-space Lines Terminate Properties: By the MDL CTFile standard, properties or data fields values are terminated by a blank line. Selecting this option will terminate the data block when encountering a line containing a space as the only character in the line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • Unwrap Long Property Lines: By the MDL CTFile standard, lines in property fields cannot exceed 200 characters. When this option is selected and a property line of exactly 200 characters is found, the newline character will be ignored and property string will continue on the next line.
  • Read Unknown Stereo Parity: When selected, the SD Reader will use the 'Atom Parity' value (parity of '3') to mark unknown stereo centers in 3D mol files. This will leave these atoms marked as 'unknown stereo' and will not calculate the stereo from the coordinates.

sci:arg.name: ReadProperties
sci:arg.sci:help: Select True to read the properties for each molecule (in addition to the structures)

sci:arg.name: ReadQueryInfo
sci:arg.sci:help: If properties starting with "QueryInfo" are present, use them to set up query information on the atoms and bonds. (This is how, for example, SMARTS query information can be preserved when writing to an MDL SD format file.) For molecules saved in MDL format, this information only contains information that cannot be written out in MDL SD format.

sci:arg.name: PutNameInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the name of each molecule

sci:arg.name: PutCommentInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the comment associated with each molecule

sci:arg.name: OnGeneralError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an recoverable error occurs during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: OnDataTypeError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an expected data type is not found during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: AllowUnknownDoubleBondsFromCoordinates
sci:arg.sci:help: According to the MDL CTfile specifications, the cis/trans character of double bonds with bond stereo set to zero is determined from the coordinates. This parameter controls whether or not to assign unknown bond stereo to double bonds for which the stereo could not be determined from the coordinates, either because there are no coordinates or because of colinearity issues. When the parameter is set to False and the stereo could not be determined, no specific stereo configuration is assigned to the double bond, but it is not marked as unknown stereo.

sci:arg.name: DeleteOnClose
sci:arg.sci:help: Delete the file after the data is read [Be Careful!]

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Reads MDL MOL (molecule CTAB) files and MDL SD (structured data) files.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: Creates a molecule data record for each molecule represented in the 'Source' data file. Can read zipped (.zip) and url-based files. Any properties contained in the file will be read into the data records created if the user specifies.Output Pass - Molecule data records

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Reads MDL MOL (molecule CTAB) files and MDL SD (structured data) files

Creates a molecular data record for each molecule represented in the Source data file. All properties contained in the file are read into the data records.

Note:

  • This component can also read zipped (.zip) and URL-based files.

See Also:

  • To write files in MDL MOL or SD format, use the SD Writer.
  • To convert a molecule to and from between text properties in CTAB format, use Molecule to CTAB and Molecule from CTAB.
  • Other related MDL format file readers include RG Reader, RXN Reader and RD Reader.
Data fields in the SD file will be added to the property fields

sci:arg.name: Counter Property
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the property to hold the data record count. If the name begins with "@", this is a global property name and is updated each time a data record is received. Otherwise, it is a local property name and a new property by that name will be created on each data record and given the current value (i.e., the count).
sci:arg.sci:member: Check if Property Already in Use

sci:arg.name: Start Index
sci:arg.sci:help: The index (i.e., number) used to start the sequence.

sci:arg.name: Check if Property Already in Use
sci:arg.sci:help: Generates an error if the property already exists. This helps prevent overwriting data created by another component. Default is "True".

sci:arg.name: OnGeneralError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an recoverable error occurs during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Counts the number of data records and puts the count in a property

Use this component to create a numerical index of data records and to keep track of the total number of records. The value of Counter Property is incremented each time a data record enters the component.

This component can be used in two modes:

  • If Counter Property is the name of a local property (does not start with "@"), a new property by that name is created on each data record and given the value of the current count.
  • If Counter Property is the name of a global property (starts with "@"), then each data record that passes through causes this global record count to be incremented, but values are not added to the passing records.

sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.sci:help: Location of the component in the database

sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help: When RunToCompletion is set to True, the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each record it processes.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Note: This is a prototype feature, which we are making availablebecause we feel it is a useful technique to improve data throughput speeds in many situations. In particular, it can help to optimize resource use on multi-CPU and multi-core machines and on server clusters.We welcome your feedback on scenarios where it works well, scenarios where it does not, and any other opinions you have about this utility.

When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help: The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware)
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: /* Server Processes must have the same number of comma separated entries as the Server parameter and must have a value*/#processes := parameter();expand(',', #processes);#servers := parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server');expand(',', #servers);if (numvalues(#processes) == 0) then SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.');else SetInvalidDetails('The number of server processes (' . numvalues(#processes) . ') must equal the number of servers (' . numvalues(#servers) . ').');end if;numvalues(#processes) > 0 and numvalues(#processes) == numvalues(#servers);
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

Use a subprotocol to collapse one or more components into a single item. Open a subprotocol to view or edit its contents.

To define input and output ports, display icon, and parameter settings, right-click and select Edit. You can save subprotocols and reuse them. For more information, see the User Guide help for Subprotocols Overview.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

Tip: Any component can be made into a shortcut, so that the latest version is always used. For more information, see Creating Shortcuts.
Records passing out of any unconnected pass ports of components inside the subprotocol

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates a SMILES representation of the molecular information in a molecular data record. SMILES is a text-based representation for molecular information developed by Daylight.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: Select either 'Smiles' or 'Canonical_Smiles" s in the 'Output' pulldown list to generate the required string. The data is augmented with the selected properties.Input - Molecule data recordsOutput Pass - Molecule data records augmented with selected properties

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates a SMILES or canonical SMILES representation of the input molecule

SMILES is a terse textual representation of molecular data. Canonical SMILES is a form of SMILES that is independent of how the molecule is drawn and so can be used to compare whether two molecules are identical.

This component can create either or both of two properties:
  • SMILES is a non-canonical representation for the molecule. (This is very fast to calculate compared to Canonical_SMILES.)
  • Canonical_SMILES is the representation that can be compared for identicality.
Note:
  • The canonicalization algorithm is SciTegic's; while it is derived from the published Daylight algorithm, however, lack of complete documentation of their procedure means that it will not necessarily give identical results. Compare two SMILES for identity only when having both canonicalized by the same method.
See Also:
  • You can create a SMILES string as text under any property name using Molecule to SMILES.
  • You can convert a SMILES string into a molecule using Molecule from SMILES.
  • For an alternative way of generating a canonical string representation, see Molecule to InChI.
Records augmented with a text property containing the canonical SMILES or SMILES

sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates a SMILES representation of the molecular information in a molecular data record. SMILES is a text-based representation for molecular information developed by Daylight.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: Select either 'Smiles' or 'Canonical_Smiles" s in the 'Output' pulldown list to generate the required string. The data is augmented with the selected properties.Input - Molecule data recordsOutput Pass - Molecule data records augmented with selected properties

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates a SMILES or canonical SMILES representation of the input molecule

SMILES is a terse textual representation of molecular data. Canonical SMILES is a form of SMILES that is independent of how the molecule is drawn and so can be used to compare whether two molecules are identical.

This component can create either or both of two properties:
  • SMILES is a non-canonical representation for the molecule. (This is very fast to calculate compared to Canonical_SMILES.)
  • Canonical_SMILES is the representation that can be compared for identicality.
Note:
  • The canonicalization algorithm is SciTegic's; while it is derived from the published Daylight algorithm, however, lack of complete documentation of their procedure means that it will not necessarily give identical results. Compare two SMILES for identity only when having both canonicalized by the same method.
See Also:
  • You can create a SMILES string as text under any property name using Molecule to SMILES.
  • You can convert a SMILES string into a molecule using Molecule from SMILES.
  • For an alternative way of generating a canonical string representation, see Molecule to InChI.
Records augmented with a text property containing the canonical SMILES or SMILES

They should not be used as input for property calculators such as Molecular Weight, pKa and others, which require the structure to be uniquely defined.

Molecular data record created from SMILES string

sci:arg.name: IgnoreProperties

sci:arg.name: MaximumDistance

sci:arg.name: NumberOfClusters

sci:arg.name: CenterSelectionMethod

sci:arg.name: RecenterCount

sci:arg.name: WhatToOutput

sci:arg.name: NumericDistanceFunction
sci:arg.sci:help:
For numeric and categorical data other than fingerprints, specifies the function to use for computing the distance between two records. Available distance functions are as follows. (For illustration, assume that each record has two numerical properties, x and y, with {x1,y1} the values for record 1 and {x2,y2} the values for record 2.)
  • RMSDifference (also known as Euclidean or L2-norm): Distance is the square-root of the sum of squared differences between corresponding property values. E.g., D = sqrt[(x1-x2)^2 + (y1-y2)^2]
  • Manhattan (also known as Hamming or L1-norm): Distance is the sum of the absolute value of the differences between corresponding property values. E.g., D = |x1-x2| + |y1-y2|.
  • OneMinusCorrelation: Distance is 1 minus the Pearson correlation between the entire vectors of property values for the two records. (With two or fewer properties on each record, this is not a meaningful distance function.)
  • OneMinusCorrelationSquared: Distance is 1 minus the square of the Pearson correlation between the entire vectors of property values for the two records. Use this function if you wish both strong correlation and strong anti-correlation to indicate that two records are "near". (With two or fewer properties on each record, this is not a meaningful distance function.)
  • AngularDistance: Each property is treated as an angle in degrees. The distance is the square-root of the sum of squared angular differences between corresponding property values. Each difference is confined to the range [0, 180], taking into account the angle periodicity. This metric should be selected when all the properties used for clustering are angle data, such as in the case of clustering conformers based on torsion angles.
  • Tanimoto: Tanimoto distance generalized to apply to continuous variables. E.g., D = 1 - (x1x2 + y1y2) / (x1^2 + x2^2 + y1^2 + y2^2 - x1x2 - y1y2). [See P. Willett et al., J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci., 38, 983 (1998).]
In the RMSDifference, Manhattan, and AngularDistance cases, the total distance for non-fingerprint properties is scaled by the number of dimensions (which is the same as the number of properties if all properties are scalars). In the RMSDifference, Manhattan, and Tanimoto cases, the "difference" between two string values is 0 if the strings are identical, or 1 if they are not. String properties are ignored for AngularDistance and the correlation options.

sci:arg.name: NumericScaling
sci:arg.sci:help:
For numeric data, the type of scaling to use.
  • MeanCenterAndScale: shifts and scales each property to have a mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1. This is the recommended option, as it puts all numeric properties on equal footing. Without such scaling, properties with a large typical magnitude (e.g., 1000) will dominate the distance calculation, while properties with a small typical magnitude (e.g., 1) will have virtually no effect.
  • None: applies no scaling to the data. This option is suitable if all numeric properties already have the same characteristic scale.

sci:arg.name: Fixed Length
sci:arg.sci:help: For efficiency, fingerprints are folded into a fixed-length bit set. This is the number of bits in that bitset.

sci:arg.name: OptimizeFor
sci:arg.sci:help: Indicates whether to optimize the clustering calculation for speed and memory or for accuracy. If optimized for accuracy, then new cluster centers will form a maximally diverse set across the entire data set. If optimized for speed and memory, then the data will be processed a chunk at a time such that the cluster centers might not be "globally" maximally diverse. Use caution when optimizing for accuracy and your data set contains more than a few thousand records, because the calculation may be much slower than when optimizing for speed and memory.

sci:arg.name: OnDataTypeError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an expected data type is not found during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: OnGeneralError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an recoverable error occurs during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: ShowSizeWhenOutputtingCenters
sci:arg.sci:help: Indicates whether to show the ClusterSize property when outputting only cluster centers. In this case, the size is always reported as 1, which can be misleading. But this parameter allows to include the ClusterSize property anyway in case it is required by a subsequent component in the pipeline.

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Assigns cluster membership numbers to the input data, using properties that you set up.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: "AvgNumberPerCluster" is the average number of molecules per cluster center. "UseProperties" selects the properties to use incalculating the distance. By default, we use properties in the PredefinedSet.'WhatToOutput' controls whether the component outputs both the cluster centers and members, or only the cluster centersYou can preselect certain molecules as cluster centers by setting the "ClusterCenter" property to 1. The clustering will then start by immediately accepting thesemolecules as cluster centers.Input - Molecular data recordsOutput Pass - The cluster centers, and possibly cluster members

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Clusters the input molecules based on molecular descriptors and adds a cluster membership property to each record.

Clustering is based on the Tanimoto distance between records, using the fingerprint property you specify. (For numeric properties, the NumericDistanceFunction specifies the distance metric to use in place of the Tanimoto distance.) The clustering method is a relocation method based on maximal dissimilarity partitioning. Full algorithmic details are available in the Modeling User Guide.

Output is one of the following:

  • All records with a new cluster membership property for each
  • Only the records selected as cluster centers

You should set the value of the AvgNumberPerCluster parameter to be the average number of molecules you wish each cluster to contain. Alternatively, you can leave this blank and set the NumberOfClusters parameter to a target number of clusters.

The Cluster Molecules component outputs the following properties:

  • Cluster: Cluster number assigned to the data record
  • DistanceToClosest: Distance to the cluster center. For fingerprints, this is the Tanimoto distance; for numeric properties, this is the NumericDistanceFunction-specified distance. For combinations of properties, the distances from each individual property are added.
  • ClusterCenter: The cluster number if the data record is a cluster center, 0 otherwise
  • ClusterSize: The total number of molecules in the cluster
Note: You can force an input record to be used as a cluster center by defining a ClusterCenter property on the record and setting its value to a number greater than 0.

See Also: Cluster Data to cluster generic data records based on non-molecular properties.
Either all molecules with properties indicating cluster membership and size, or just molecules representing cluster centers
Data records with missing or invalid property values, with an added ErrorText property containing a message explaining the failure

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: Location of the component in the database

sci:arg.name: MergeUsing
sci:arg.sci:help:
Name of the property (or a comma-separated list of properties) that will be used to merge on. Data records having the same value for this property will be merged. This property must contain scalar (i.e., non-array) data.

If multiple properties are specified, the values must be the same for all of the properties (unless MergeUsingListType is set to UseFirstDefinedValue).

sci:arg.name: MergeUsingListType
sci:arg.sci:help:
How MergeUsing properties are interpreted when more than one property is listed:

  • "UseFirstDefinedValue": Use only the first property in the list that has a defined value for a record as the merge key.
  • UseAllValues: Use the concatentation of values of all properties listed as the merge key.

sci:arg.name: MergePropertyType
sci:arg.sci:help:
The types of values found in the property specified by MergeUsing:

  • IsNumeric: All numbers are converted to doubles for comparison (e.g., 1 = 1.0).
  • IsText: All comparisons are made as string values.
  • IsDate: The key is considered a date.
  • IsFingerprint: The key is considered a fingerprint. Fingerprint bits are sorted before making the comparison.

sci:arg.name: IgnoreCase
sci:arg.sci:help: Considers lower-case and upper-case letters as equivalent when determining the identity of "MergeUsing" property values.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergePropertyType to IsText');Parameter('MergePropertyType') eq 'IsText'

sci:arg.name: MergeBehavior
sci:arg.sci:help:
Controls how properties, other than the MergeUsing property, are handled.

  • KeepAll: Keeps all property values by appending values into an array.
  • KeepFirst: Keeps only the properties and values from the first example received. All properties and values from subsequent records matching the property specified by MergeUsing are discarded.

sci:arg.name: WhenMerging
sci:arg.sci:help:
When merging using KeepAll behavior, provides fine control over how multiple values are treated.

  • OverwriteOrCreate: Copies all properties of each merged record sequentially, overwriting any values that may already exist (instead of generating an array).
  • OverwriteExisting: Only copies properties that already exist on the first merged record, overwriting those original values (instead of creating an array).
  • CreateIfNew: Leaves any existing properties alone, and writes only new properties.
  • AppendOrCreate: Appends (as an array) if a property already exists, otherwise creates it.
  • AppendExisting: Appends (as an array) only to currently existing properties, and discards other new property values.

sci:arg.name: KeepAllNullString
sci:arg.sci:help: This string is used during append using KeepAll MergeBehavior to pad out empty values. It keeps the number of values of generated arrays of values the same, and in sync, for multiple samples. The default value is None, which causes no padding to occur.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergeBehavior to KeepAll');Parameter('MergeBehavior') eq 'KeepAll'

sci:arg.name: KeepAllPreferredNodeName
sci:arg.sci:help: If defined, and MergeBehavior is KeepAll, this contains a name that is used to prioritize which underlying data record should be kept. If not defined, the first record with a given merge value is kept; if this is defined, and at least one of the data records contains a node of this type, then the first example of that type is kept.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable, set MergeBehavior to KeepAll');Parameter('MergeBehavior') eq 'KeepAll'

sci:arg.name: PrefixUsingProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: When multiple values for a property are retained (under KeepAll merge behavior), the original property name is prefixed differently for each original value it must hold. The prefix is constructed from the value of this property, followed by an underscore.When not specified, a prefix is not used and multiple values are separated as an array (such as property[1], property[2], etc).

sci:arg.name: OutputFrequency
sci:arg.sci:help: Add a property called "Frequency" that contains the number of individual records included in the resulting merged record.

sci:arg.name: OnGeneralError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an recoverable error occurs during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: OnDataTypeError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an expected data type is not found during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: AcceptNonNumericStringsAsNumbers
sci:arg.sci:help: Determines whether all string values for the MergeUsing property -- even non-numeric ones such as 'abc' or '1.0c' -- will be coerced to numbers when MergePropertyType is set to IsNumeric. If set to True, then a string such as 'abc' that does not begin with a numeric portion will be coerced to zero, while a string such as '1.0c' that begins with a numeric portion will be coerced to the corresponding number (in this case 1.0). If set to False, then records containing non-numeric strings for the MergeUsing property will be sent out the Fail port.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Merges multiple data objects into one when they have the same value for a given property name.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: Incoming data records are merged into a single data record if they have the same value as each other for the 'MergeUsing' named property(s). (If multiple 'MergeUsing' names are given, all must be identical for a merge event to occur.'MergeBehavior' can be KeepAll, which keeps all values by appending any new ones; KeepFirst, which only keeps the properties of the first record found, and KeepTogether, which keeps matching items sequentially together (like Sort).'IgnoreCase' tells whether to ignore lettercase when comparing values as text.'OutputFrequency' tells whether a property Frequency should be added to the merged output data, and containing the number of equivalent items found.The properties of merged data records are appended in the form of an array. unless a 'PrefixUsingProperty' is given, so the value of the given property is prepended to each property name on each data item. This is often useful when merging multiple data files with a 'SourceTag' parameter (available in many readers).When records containing molecular structures are merged, only the molecular structure of the first record seen is retained in the final merged data record.Input - Data recordsOutput Pass - Merged data recordsOutput Fail - Data records which did not contain values for the 'MergeUsing' namesADVANCED PROPERTIES'KeepAllNullString', if not equal to the word None, is a string that is used to pad the output values so that if N items are merged, all properties are arrays of length N. This keeps the property values in sync.'MergeUsingListType' is by default ConcatenateValue, which means a concatenation of all the MergeUsing values is used to compare data records. UseFirstDefinedValue uses the first defined value in the MergeUsing list to compare the data.'MergePropertyType' is by default IsText. To compare as numbers, use IsNumeric.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Merges properties of all data records that share the same key property value into a single data record

Incoming data records are merged into a single data record if they have the same value for the MergeUsing property.

MergeBehavior controls how properties, other than the MergeUsing property, are handled.

Note:
  • Multiple MergeUsing properties can be specified. In this case, data records are merged if the value for each MergeUsing property matches across the data records.

See Also:

  • If you wish to merge records based on molecular structures, use Merge Molecules (which requires the Chemistry Collection).
Data records that contain the properties being used for merging
Data records that do not contain the properties being used for merging

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: Location of the component in the database

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help: When RunToCompletion is set to True, the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each record it processes.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Note: This is a prototype feature, which we are making availablebecause we feel it is a useful technique to improve data throughput speeds in many situations. In particular, it can help to optimize resource use on multi-CPU and multi-core machines and on server clusters.We welcome your feedback on scenarios where it works well, scenarios where it does not, and any other opinions you have about this utility.

When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help: The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware)
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: /* Server Processes must have the same number of comma separated entries as the Server parameter and must have a value*/#processes := parameter();expand(',', #processes);#servers := parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server');expand(',', #servers);if (numvalues(#processes) == 0) then SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.');else SetInvalidDetails('The number of server processes (' . numvalues(#processes) . ') must equal the number of servers (' . numvalues(#servers) . ').');end if;numvalues(#processes) > 0 and numvalues(#processes) == numvalues(#servers);
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

To define input and output ports, display icon, and parameter settings, right-click and select Edit. You can save subprotocols and reuse them. For more information, see the User Guide help for Subprotocols Overview.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

Tip: Any component can be made into a shortcut, so that the latest version is always used. For more information, see Creating Shortcuts.

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Allows you to filter using the result from a PilotScript expression. The expression you specify is evaluated for each incoming data record, and is evaluated to a True or False value. If multiple statements are present, then the value of the last statement is used.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: The 'Expression' is evaluated for each incoming data record. The last statement in the expression evaluates to a boolean value (true/false or nonzero/zero) and determines the fate of the data record: Records which evaluate to 'true' are passed out the Pass port; those which evaluate to 'false' are passed out the 'Fail' port.Input - Data recordsOutput Pass - Data records which evaluate 'true'Output Fail - Data records which evaluate 'false'

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Passes data records for which a PilotScript expression evaluates to True

For each incoming data record, the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated. If the last statement in the expression evaluates to True or non-zero, the record is sent out the Pass port. Otherwise it is sent out the Fail port.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax and can only be accessed by token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.
Data records for which the final expression in the PilotScript evaluates to True or non-zero
Data records for which the final expression in the PilotScript evaluates to False or zero

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Contains a number of actions that are useful for taking molecules from different sources and correcting non-uniform features.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: One or more actions can be applied to each molecule to standardize the way molecules are presented to downstream components.Input - Molecular data recordsOutput Pass - Molecular data records with standardization changesDescription of StandardizeStereo option:Atoms that are perceived as true stereo atoms but which have no stereochemical markings (UnknownAtomStereo, EvenAtomStereo, or OddAtomStereo) are set to UnknownAtomStereo. Atoms that have stereochemical markings but which are not true stereoatoms are set to NoAtomStereo. 2D or 3D coordinates are not used in this process.Similarly, bonds that are perceived as true stereo double bonds but which have no stereochemical markings (UnknownBondStereo, CisBondStereo, or TransBondStereo) are set to UnknownBondStereo. Bonds that have stereochemical markings but which are not true stereo bonds are set to NoBondStereo. Again, 2D or 3D coordinates are not used in this process.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies selected predefined actions to the input molecules

One or more actions can be applied to each molecule to standardize the way molecules are presented to downstream components.

Standardization is important when comparing molecular libraries from different sources. If different rules were used for structural representation when creating these libraries, a straight comparison would yield incorrect results. This component allows you to apply a consistent set of rules to structures before comparing them.

Available actions:

  • StandardizeStereo: Atoms that are perceived as true stereo atoms but which have no stereochemical markings (UnknownAtomStereo, EvenAtomStereo, or OddAtomStereo) are set to UnknownAtomStereo. Atoms that have stereochemical markings but which are not true stereoatoms are set to NoAtomStereo. 2D or 3D coordinates are not used in this process.
    Similarly, bonds that are perceived as true stereo double bonds, but which have no stereochemical markings (UnknownBondStereo, CisBondStereo, or TransBondStereo) are set to UnknownBondStereo. Bonds that have stereochemical markings but which are not true stereo bonds are set to NoBondStereo. Again, 2D or 3D coordinates are not used in this process.
  • StandardizeCharges: Sets standard formal charges for common functional groups: Quaternary Nitrogen: +1
    Nitro groups: N+(=O)O-
    Diazonium N: +1
    Oxygen with three attachments: +1
    X=O-C Oxygen: +1
    Sulfur with three attachments: +1
    S=O-C Sulfur: +1
    F, Cl, Br, I with no attachments: -1
    Note that halogen acids with explicit hydrogens (H-X) are not modified.
  • CenterMolecule: Translates the molecule to the center of geometry.
  • RemoveSingleAtomFragments: Removes all unattached atoms from the molecule.
  • KeepSmallestFragment: Keeps only the fragment with fewer atoms in the case of multifragment molecules.
  • MakeNon[H]Atoms[C]Atoms: Converts all the atoms in the molecule to Carbon.
  • MakeNon[C,H]Atoms[Q]Atoms: Converts all non-carbon, non-hydrogen atoms in the molecule to the Q query atom type.
  • MakeNon[H]Atoms[A]Atoms: Converts all non-hydrogen atoms in the molecule to the A query atom type.
  • MakeAllBondsSingle: Converts all the bonds in the molecule to Single bonds.
  • ClearCoordinates: Sets all x, y, z coordinates to zero.
  • ClearMolecule: Deletes all atoms and bonds in the molecule, keeping the molecule object in the data record.
  • RemoveMolecule: Deletes the molecule object from the data record.
  • ClearStereo: Sets all atoms and bonds to NoStereo.
  • ClearUnknownStereo: Sets all atoms and bonds that are marked UnknownStereo to NoStereo.
  • ClearCisTransBondStereo: Sets all bonds that are marked CisStereo or TransStereo to UnknownStereo.
  • ClearCharges: Sets all formal charges to zero.
  • SetStereoFromCoordinates: This option uses the 2D coordinates and up/down bond markings, or the 3D coordinates, to assign the stereochemistry of the atoms or bonds. Typically, this is done by the readers or the molecules from text components. Occasionally, components may create molecules that need to have their stereo reperceived.
  • RepositionStereoBonds: This option repositions the stereo bond markings, trying to find the best bond to mark as a wedge bond for each stereo atom.
  • FixDirectionOfWedgeBonds: This option checks the wedge bonds in the molecule to make sure that the wedge is drawn with the stereo atom at the narrow end of the wedge. Any wedge bond for which there is a stereo atom at the wide end and no stereo atom at the narrow end is reversed to point in the other direction. A separate option, Invert Wedge Bond When Changing Direction, controls whether or not to invert the bond stereo (up or down) when changing the direction of the wedge bond.
  • ClearQueryInfo: Deletes all query information from atoms and bonds.
  • NeutralizeBondedZwitterions: Converts directly bonded zwitterions (positively charged atom bonded to negatively charged atom, A+B-) to the neutral representation (A=B).
  • ClearSGroupData: Clears any SGroup information from the molecule.
  • ClearHighlightColors: Clears any highlight colors from atoms and bonds.
  • ClearAtomLabels: Clears any labels assigned to the atoms.
  • ClearBondLabels: Clears any labels assigned to the bonds.
  • NeutralizeBondedZwitterions: Converts directly bonded zwitterions (positively charged atom bonded to negatively charged atom, A+B-) to the neutral representation (A=B)
  • ClearUnusualValence: Clears any atom valence query features and resets all implicit hydrogen counts to their standard values.

sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: The 'Expression' is evaluated for each data record, and may alter and manipulate the properties of the data objects. The 'Initial expression' is evaluated the first time data passes into the component and is typically used for initializing global variables. See the online documentation for full details of PilotScript expression syntax.Input - Data recordsOutput Pass - All Data records

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax and can only be accessed by token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

sci:arg.sci:help: The names of the one or more properties to separate and return as separate data records. If no property names are given, then all properties withmultiple values will be unmerged. If multiple properties are unmerged, the number of unmerged records is the number of values of a property with the maximum number of values.

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Separates data records containing multiple values into multiple duplicate records each containing only one of the values.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: Each incoming data record with more than one value in the specified property is duplicated for each of the multiple values. For example, a data object with three values would generate three data objects, each with only one of the three values (but otherwise identical).If no property names are given, then all properties with multiple values are unmerged.If multiple properties are unmerged, they must contain the same number of values.Input - Data recordsOutput Pass - Data records (containing the separated values)

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Separates data records containing array properties into individual records with one array value per record

Each incoming data record with more than one value for the property or properties specified by PropertyNames is duplicated for each of the values. For example, a input data record with three values will generate three output data records. Each output record will contain one of the values for the PropertyNames property, and all other properties will be identical.

Notes:
  • If no property names are given, then all properties with multiple values are unmerged. In this case, unexpected occurrences of arrays in a property will cause unintentional unmerge operations. Try to specify a value for PropertyNames if possible.
  • If multiple unmerge properties are specified, the number of data records that result from unmerging a given incoming data record is equal to the number of values of the unmerge property that has the most values. That is, if two unmerge properties, "A" and "B" are specified where A has 5 values and B has 7 values, then 7 data records will result. The first 5 records will contain, in order, the 5 values of A. For the last two records, A will be undefined. All other properties will be duplicated on each record.
Data records containing the separated values for the property or properties specified.

sci:arg.sci:help: The optional title of the HTML document

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Generates and displays an HTML table page of molecules and their properties.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: This component will generate and display an HTML page in Internet Explorer of molecules and their associated properties as a table with a single molecule per row. See also the 'HTML Grouped Viewer' and 'HTML Cluster Viewer' for alternative displays of multiple molecules

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Displays data records as HTML in Internet Explorer

Generates and displays an HTML table page of data records, with one record per row. Each property becomes a column in the table and each value a cell.

Notes:

  • Molecules will be displayed if present.
  • For hierarchical data records, only top level properties are displayed.
  • Any grouped data is displayed in nested tables.
See Also:
  • If you prefer not to view the grouped data, use Delete Children.
  • For more control over the display of molecules, use HTML Molecular Table Viewer.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: Location of the component in the database

sci:arg.name: Source
sci:arg.sci:help: The file or URL source to read

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to read (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: SourceTag
sci:arg.sci:help:
The type of tag to create to identify the source of data records. A property called SourceTag is created and holds the value indicated.

  • None: No SourceTag property is created and any existing ones are removed.
  • Filename: The name of the file read.
  • FilenameAndExtension: The name of the file read with its file extension.
  • FullFilename: The name of the file read, including the directory path.
  • ZipFilename: When reading a compressed zip file, the filename within the compressed archive.
  • Number: When multiple files are read in this component, they are numbered 1,2,3...
  • Letter: When multiple files are read in this component, they are lettered A, B, C...
  • KeepCurrent: Keeps the current value of SourceTag.

sci:arg.name: Keep Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: A list of properties the reader should retain for each data record that is output. If a value is not defined, retains all properties. If the parameter contains the value "-" (minus sign), properties are not retained.

sci:arg.name: SD Format Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Options available for the SD Reader:

  • Properties Can Contain $$$$: By the MDL CTFile standard, a property can contain a '$$$$'-line. Properties or data field values are terminated by a blank line. Only then will the '$$$$'-line terminate the full data block. Setting this option off will terminate the data block upon any read of a '$$$$'-line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • One-space Lines Terminate Properties: By the MDL CTFile standard, properties or data fields values are terminated by a blank line. Selecting this option will terminate the data block when encountering a line containing a space as the only character in the line. This option is available to provide compatibility with some 3rd Party SD files.
  • Unwrap Long Property Lines: By the MDL CTFile standard, lines in property fields cannot exceed 200 characters. When this option is selected and a property line of exactly 200 characters is found, the newline character will be ignored and property string will continue on the next line.
  • Read Unknown Stereo Parity: When selected, the SD Reader will use the 'Atom Parity' value (parity of '3') to mark unknown stereo centers in 3D mol files. This will leave these atoms marked as 'unknown stereo' and will not calculate the stereo from the coordinates.

sci:arg.name: ReadProperties
sci:arg.sci:help: Select True to read the properties for each molecule (in addition to the structures)

sci:arg.name: ReadQueryInfo
sci:arg.sci:help: If properties starting with "QueryInfo" are present, use them to set up query information on the atoms and bonds. (This is how, for example, SMARTS query information can be preserved when writing to an MDL SD format file.) For molecules saved in MDL format, this information only contains information that cannot be written out in MDL SD format.

sci:arg.name: PutNameInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the name of each molecule

sci:arg.name: PutCommentInProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: What to call the property that holds the comment associated with each molecule

sci:arg.name: OnGeneralError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an recoverable error occurs during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: OnDataTypeError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an expected data type is not found during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: AllowUnknownDoubleBondsFromCoordinates
sci:arg.sci:help: According to the MDL CTfile specifications, the cis/trans character of double bonds with bond stereo set to zero is determined from the coordinates. This parameter controls whether or not to assign unknown bond stereo to double bonds for which the stereo could not be determined from the coordinates, either because there are no coordinates or because of colinearity issues. When the parameter is set to False and the stereo could not be determined, no specific stereo configuration is assigned to the double bond, but it is not marked as unknown stereo.

sci:arg.name: DeleteOnClose
sci:arg.sci:help: Delete the file after the data is read [Be Careful!]

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Reads MDL MOL (molecule CTAB) files and MDL SD (structured data) files.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: Creates a molecule data record for each molecule represented in the 'Source' data file. Can read zipped (.zip) and url-based files. Any properties contained in the file will be read into the data records created if the user specifies.Output Pass - Molecule data records

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Reads MDL MOL (molecule CTAB) files and MDL SD (structured data) files

Creates a molecular data record for each molecule represented in the Source data file. All properties contained in the file are read into the data records.

Note:

  • This component can also read zipped (.zip) and URL-based files.

See Also:

  • To write files in MDL MOL or SD format, use the SD Writer.
  • To convert a molecule to and from between text properties in CTAB format, use Molecule to CTAB and Molecule from CTAB.
  • Other related MDL format file readers include RG Reader, RXN Reader and RD Reader.
Data fields in the SD file will be added to the property fields

sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the property to hold the data record count. If the name begins with "@", this is a global property name and is updated each time a data record is received. Otherwise, it is a local property name and a new property by that name will be created on each data record and given the current value (i.e., the count).

sci:arg.name: Start Index
sci:arg.sci:help: The index (i.e., number) used to start the sequence.

sci:arg.name: Check if Property Already in Use

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Counts the number of data records and puts the count in a property

Use this component to create a numerical index of data records and to keep track of the total number of records. The value of Counter Property is incremented each time a data record enters the component.

This component can be used in two modes:

  • If Counter Property is the name of a local property (does not start with "@"), a new property by that name is created on each data record and given the value of the current count.
  • If Counter Property is the name of a global property (starts with "@"), then each data record that passes through causes this global record count to be incremented, but values are not added to the passing records.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: Location of the component in the database

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help: When RunToCompletion is set to True, the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each record it processes.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
Note: This is a prototype feature, which we are making availablebecause we feel it is a useful technique to improve data throughput speeds in many situations. In particular, it can help to optimize resource use on multi-CPU and multi-core machines and on server clusters.We welcome your feedback on scenarios where it works well, scenarios where it does not, and any other opinions you have about this utility.

When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help: The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware)
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: /* Server Processes must have the same number of comma separated entries as the Server parameter and must have a value*/#processes := parameter();expand(',', #processes);#servers := parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server');expand(',', #servers);if (numvalues(#processes) == 0) then SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.');else SetInvalidDetails('The number of server processes (' . numvalues(#processes) . ') must equal the number of servers (' . numvalues(#servers) . ').');end if;numvalues(#processes) > 0 and numvalues(#processes) == numvalues(#servers);
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'");Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

To define input and output ports, display icon, and parameter settings, right-click and select Edit. You can save subprotocols and reuse them. For more information, see the User Guide help for Subprotocols Overview.

  • Canonical_SMILES is the representation that can be compared for identicality.

sci:arg.name: ComponentComment
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates a SMILES representation of the molecular information in a molecular data record. SMILES is a text-based representation for molecular information developed by Daylight.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: Select either 'Smiles' or 'Canonical_Smiles" s in the 'Output' pulldown list to generate the required string. The data is augmented with the selected properties.Input - Molecule data recordsOutput Pass - Molecule data records augmented with selected properties

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates a SMILES or canonical SMILES representation of the input molecule

SMILES is a terse textual representation of molecular data. Canonical SMILES is a form of SMILES that is independent of how the molecule is drawn and so can be used to compare whether two molecules are identical.

This component can create either or both of two properties:
  • SMILES is a non-canonical representation for the molecule. (This is very fast to calculate compared to Canonical_SMILES.)
  • Canonical_SMILES is the representation that can be compared for identicality.
Note:
  • The canonicalization algorithm is SciTegic's; while it is derived from the published Daylight algorithm, however, lack of complete documentation of their procedure means that it will not necessarily give identical results. Compare two SMILES for identity only when having both canonicalized by the same method.
See Also:
  • You can create a SMILES string as text under any property name using Molecule to SMILES.
  • You can convert a SMILES string into a molecule using Molecule from SMILES.
  • For an alternative way of generating a canonical string representation, see Molecule to InChI.
Records augmented with a text property containing the canonical SMILES or SMILES

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: Select either 'Smiles' or 'Canonical_Smiles" s in the 'Output' pulldown list to generate the required string. The data is augmented with the selected properties.Input - Molecule data recordsOutput Pass - Molecule data records augmented with selected properties

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Calculates a SMILES or canonical SMILES representation of the input molecule

SMILES is a terse textual representation of molecular data. Canonical SMILES is a form of SMILES that is independent of how the molecule is drawn and so can be used to compare whether two molecules are identical.

This component can create either or both of two properties:
  • SMILES is a non-canonical representation for the molecule. (This is very fast to calculate compared to Canonical_SMILES.)
  • Canonical_SMILES is the representation that can be compared for identicality.
Note:
  • The canonicalization algorithm is SciTegic's; while it is derived from the published Daylight algorithm, however, lack of complete documentation of their procedure means that it will not necessarily give identical results. Compare two SMILES for identity only when having both canonicalized by the same method.
See Also:
  • You can create a SMILES string as text under any property name using Molecule to SMILES.
  • You can convert a SMILES string into a molecule using Molecule from SMILES.
  • For an alternative way of generating a canonical string representation, see Molecule to InChI.
Records augmented with a text property containing the canonical SMILES or SMILES

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: Location of the component in the database

sci:arg.name: FromProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: The name of the property in the datawhich holds the SMILES information

sci:arg.name: KekulizeAromaticBonds
sci:arg.sci:help: Turn aromatic bonds into single/double bonds (set to True) or into aromatic query bonds (set to False). Molecules created with aromatic query bonds are more suitable as queries than as specific molecules. They should not be used as input for property calculators such as Molecular Weight, pKa and others, which require the structure to be uniquely defined.

sci:arg.name: OnGeneralError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an recoverable error occurs during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.name: OnDataTypeError
sci:arg.sci:help: When an expected data type is not found during processing: Halt: Terminate the execution of the network Fail: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Fail(red) port Pass: Continue execution of the network, passing data out the Pass(green) port

sci:arg.sci:value: Takes a Daylight SMILES string as text on a given property and converts the object into a SciTegic molecule using that information.

sci:arg.name: ComponentUsage
sci:arg.sci:value: A molecular representation is built for each data record from the SMILES data found in the property list. *Note that if a molecular representation is already present, it will be overwritten by the new molecule.Input - Data recordsOutput Pass - Molecular data records

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Converts a Daylight SMILES text property to a molecule

Builds a molecular representation for each data record from the SMILES string found in the property list. If a molecular representation is already present, it is overwritten by the new molecule. The input SMILES string is preserved.

See Also:

  • To create a string property containing SMILES data, use Molecule to SMILES or Canonical Smiles.
  • To read and write SMILES files, use SMILES Reader and SMILES Writer.
Molecular data record created from SMILES string
